Expectation1: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation1: The task has generous buffer time and others can proceed without it for a while.
Situation2: They must follow strict procedures for a large cash deposit at the end of a busy shift to comply with corporate auditing rules.
Story: I glanced at the clock on my computer, the numbers blurring together as I tried to focus on the spreadsheet in front of me. As a colleague, I knew I was expected to finish my part of the project by the end of the day, but there was still plenty of buffer time. My teammates could keep working without my section for now, and I could always stay a bit late tomorrow if needed. But as the end of my shift approached, my other role tugged at me—cashier. The store manager had just reminded us about the new corporate policy: every large cash deposit had to be counted, double-checked, and logged with no shortcuts, no matter how late it was or how tired we felt. The process was tedious and time-consuming, but skipping a step could mean trouble for everyone. I felt the weight of both roles pressing down on me—my colleagues counting on me to keep the project moving, and the company relying on me to follow every rule to the letter. My mind raced, torn between the easy flexibility of my office work and the rigid demands of the register, unsure which responsibility to put first.
